question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

6. Let $f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$. Note that the domain of $f$ is the
set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, $f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

(a) Determine the interval(s) where $f(x)$ is increasing, and the
interval(s) where $f(x)$ is decreasing.
sols:
Differentiating $\displaystyle f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$ gives

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{6x^{-2/5}}{5} + \frac{-6x^{-7/5}}{5} = \frac{6x^{-7/5}}{5}(x-1)$.

Thus the critical numbers are $x=1$ and $x=0$ (notice here our
derivative and our function are both undefined). So we check the
intervals $\displaystyle (-\infty,0),(0,1),(1,\infty)$ individually.

Case 1\begin{align*}\displaystyle (-\infty,0)\end{align*}

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say $x = -1$,
which gives a value of $12/5 > 0$. Thus the function is increasing on
this interval.

Case 2\begin{align*}\displaystyle (0,1)\end{align*}

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say $x = 1/2$,
which gives a value of $6\cdot 2^{7/5}/5(-1/2) < 0$. Thus the function
is decreasing on this interval.

Case 3\begin{align*}\displaystyle (1,\infty)\end{align*}

We test that the derivative at a point in the interval, say $x = 2$,
which gives a value of $6\cdot 2^{-7/5}/5 > 0$. Thus the function is
increasing on this interval.

\textbf{Summary}

Overall, the function in increasing on $(-\infty, 0) \cup (1, \infty)$
and decreasing on $\displaystyle (0, 1)$.
